DataElementConcept.preferredName: Patient Secondary B Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Development Therapeutic Procedure Prior Malignant Neoplasm With Cytotoxic Chemotherapy Eligibility Determination
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary._Derived as a result of a primary condition; not direct or immediate; of second rank or importance or value._The most frequent type of acute lymphoblastic leukemia.  Approximately 75% of cases occur in children under six years of age.  This is a good prognosis leukemia.  In the pediatric age group the complete remission rate is approximately 95% and the disease free survival rate is 70%.  Approximately 80% of children appear to be cured.  In the adult age group the complete remission rate is 60-85%.  (WHO, 2001)_Processes that involve and promote formation of more mature organs, organ systems, or organisms; general development. (NCI)_An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process._Earlier in time or order._A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas._Used to indicate the presence of something or someone._Anticancer drugs that kill cells, especially cancer cells._The act of determining if a subject is suitable for enrollment in a study according specific protocol criteria and procedures.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A person who requires medical care.

Concepts.definition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.

Property.preferredName: Secondary B Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Development Therapeutic Procedure Prior Malignant Neoplasm With Cytotoxic Chemotherapy Eligibility Determination
Property.preferredDefinition: Derived as a result of a primary condition; not direct or immediate; of second rank or importance or value.:The most frequent type of acute lymphoblastic leukemia.  Approximately 75 percent of cases occur in children under six years of age.  This is a good prognosis leukemia.  In the pediatric age group the complete remission rate is approximately 95 percent and the disease free survival rate is 70 percent.  Approximately 80 percent of children appear to be cured.  In the adult age group the complete remission rate is 60-85 percent.  (WHO, 2001):Processes that involve and promote formation of more mature organs, organ systems, or organisms; general development. (NCI):An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.:Earlier in time or order.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.:Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.:Anticancer drugs that kill cells, especially cancer cells.:Criteria to determine eligibility of patients for medical care programs and services.

Concepts.definition: Derived as a result of a primary condition; not direct or immediate; of second rank or importance or value.

The most frequent type of acute lymphoblastic leukemia.  Approximately 75% of cases occur in children under six years of age.  This is a good prognosis leukemia.  In the pediatric age group the complete remission rate is approximately 95% and the disease free survival rate is 70%.  Approximately 80% of children appear to be cured.  In the adult age group the complete remission rate is 60-85%.  (WHO, 2001)
Processes that involve and promote formation of more mature organs, organ systems, or organisms; general development. (NCI)
An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.
A drug therapy that is used to destroy cancer cells.
The act of determining if a subject is suitable for enrollment in a study according specific protocol criteria and procedures.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: trial-specific criteria that a patient must meet to be enrolled.
